questions.text: Women with bacterial vaginosis are treated with which of the following drugs
questions.solution:
Metronidazole is the drug of choice for bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: In preeclampsia, the loading dose of MgSO4 is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. 8 ml MgSO4 (50% w/v) with 12 ml N.S

According to Pritchard regime:
The loading dose is 4 gm of 20% MgSO4 administered intravenously and 5 gm of 50% MgSO4 administered intramuscularly in each buttock.

IV Dose preparation:
In 20 ml syringe: 4 ampoules of MgSO4 + add 12 ml NS
1 ampoule MgSO4= 2 ml MgSO4= 1 gm MgSO4
Therefore, In 20 ml syringe 8 ml MgSO4 + 12 ml of NS is added


According to Zuspan or Sibai IV regime:  Give 4- to 6-g loading dose of magnesium sulfate diluted in 100 ml of IV fluid administered over 15-20 min as Loading dose. Followed by 2 g/hr in 100 ml of IV maintenance dose.

questions.text: Name the fracture.
questions.solution:
Galeazzi Fracture: A direct impact to the radius causes a diaphyseal fracture and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.
XRay:
Lateral view: Radius is dorsally angulated.
APview: Transverse or short oblique fracture radius. The distal radioulnar joint dislocation.
 
  • The Monteggia fracture is a dislocated fracture of the upper portion of the ulna and head of radius is dislocated.  Late childhood is the most typical time. It happens when you fall with your hands outstretched, either in hyperpronation or hyperextension.
  • Distal radius is involved in a colles fracture. frequently happens as a result of a fall onto a hand that is outstretched, resulting in a dorsally displaced, dorsally angulated fracture. frequently observed in kids and the elderly (osteoporosis).
  • A T- or Y-shaped intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal is known as a Rolando's fracture.

questions.text: Maltese cross in urine is seen in
questions.solution:
• The nephropathy of Fabry’s disease typically presents in the third decade as mild to moderate proteinuria, sometimes with microscopic hematuria or nephrotic syndrome. 
  • Urine examination in Fabry disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarised light showing a Maltese cross appearance.

questions.text: In which of the aminoacid replacements, its normal charge is not altered?
questions.solution:
In this question, the idea of conservative or homologous replacement of amino acids is covered. 
If a substituted amino acid falls under the same classification like hydrophobic or hydrophilic, its function will not change.
Since glutamine and asparagine are both uncharged polar (hydrophilic) amino acids, the right response is glutamine to asparagine. As a result, there is no change in the polarity or charge of the peptide/protein when asparagine is substituted.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 4.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to repair DNA in CRISPR-CAS 9?
questions.solution:
The primary method of gene repair by CRISPR-Cas9 is non homologous end joining (NHEJ) repair.

CRISPR  stands for Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats.

The genome-editing technique CRISPR-Cas-9 allows specific bacteria to access genetic material.

The transcription of CRISPRs results in an RNA sequence that directs Cas-9 to a sequence that causes cleavage.

An artificial guide-RNA used in gene editing binds to Cas-9 and is complementary to the DNA sequence of interest. Double-stranded DNA breaks, also known as Double-Stranded Breaks (DSBs), are brought about by Cas9.

Then, NHEJ repair and homologous repair are used to repair DCBs. The more important of the two pathways is NHEJ repair because eukaryotes have a relatively poor homologous repair efficiency.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 413.

questions.text: A patient with renal failure and anemia comes. Serum Protein Electrophoresis is shown below. What's the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The large spike in the gamma region (M Spike) points toward a diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma.

Renal Failure and anemia are a part of end-organ damage (CRAB criteria of Multiple Myeloma).
In nephrotic syndrome, alpha-2 region spike is seen.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 868, 871.

questions.text: In which of the following do we use the Z tracking technique ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Administering long-acting antipsychotics
 
  • Patients with psychosis or manic episodes who don't adhere to oral medication are administered LAAls i.e long-acting anti-psychotic depot injections. Intramuscular administration is the method of choice.
  • With the exception of the deltoid, all injection sites follow the Z track approach. The skin is pulled laterally away from the injection site before the needle is inserted at a 90° angle. Skin is loosened to allow the dislodged tissue to cover the needle track after 10 seconds of drug injection.
  • It is done to maximize absorption in muscle by preventing the drug from moving back to subcutaneous tissue.
  • This technique is also used to inject iron.
Online Reference: Devrımcı Özgüven H, Kir Y. Long Acting Injectable Antipsychotics in the Treatment of Schizophrenia and Bipolar Disorder. Noro Psikiyatr Ars. 2021 Sep 20;58(Suppl 1):S47-S52. doi: 10.29399/npa.27480. PMID: 34658635; PMCID: PMC8498817.

questions.solution:
Hemorrhagic mediastinitis is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax.

Bacillus anthracis is the organism causing anthrax. It is a spore-producing, gram-positive rod found in sheep, cattle, horses, and goats.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Iron absorption is decreased by Hepcidin by inhibiting
questions.solution:
Iron is maximally absorbed from the duodenum.

The liver synthesizes hepcidin which is a key regulator of iron metabolism.
It supresses the basolateral transfer of iron from enterocyte into the bloodstream by
downregulating ferroportin.

A portion of the dietary iron is typically carried into the enterocytes through the divalent metal transporter 1;
some iron is stored while the remaining iron is subsequently removed from the enterocyte through the basolateral protein ferroportin 1.

The HFE gene controls the amount of hepcidin.
HFE gene mutation - hemochromatosis.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 477

questions.text: The entry of iron in enterocyte is by -
questions.solution:
A portion of the dietary iron (Fe2) is typically carried into the enterocytes through the Divalent metal transporter 1(DMT-1) (Option 1)

Some iron is stored while the remaining iron is subsequently removed from the enterocyte through the basolateral protein ferroportin 1.

questions.text: The binding of mRNA with ribosomes in eukaryotes is guided by which of the following ?
questions.solution:
mRNA has poly-A tails at the 3' end and a 7-methylguanosine cap at the 5' end.
The ribosome is able to identify the site of attachment to the mRNA with the help of the 7-methylguanosine caps.
Following the ribosome's binding to the 5' end, it scans downstream until it comes across an AUG Codon (Start codon)
The polyadenylation sequence (Poly A tail), which is located at the 3' end, helps stabilise the mRNA, facilitates its escape from the nucleus, and aids in translation.
The length of the poly-A tails steadily shortens as the mRNA moves into the cytosol.
The tRNA molecule functions as adaptors for the conversion of the information contained in the mRNA's nucleotide sequence into particular amino acids.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 457.

questions.text: Which is a deficiency amidst the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image is representative of the Casals necklace, which is seen in pellagra and denotes tryptophan deficiency.
Pellagra can occur due to:
Vitamin B3 (Niacin)- which is produced from tryptophan and requires vitamins B2 and B6 for its production, may contribute to pellagra.
Hartnups disease: Tryptophan malabsorption is caused by Hartnups disease, which is caused by a defect in the membrane transport of tryptophan across PCT and enterocytes. A tryptophan deficiency results from this.
Carcinoid syndrome: Increased serotonin production causes tryptophan to be diverted away from the NAD+ pathway.
Vitamin B6 deficiency: Niacin production is hampered in cases of vitamin B6 insufficiency due to deficient kynureninase.

questions.text: Which among the following conditions will precipitate delirium tremens in a known alcoholic?
questions.solution:
Delirium tremors in an alcoholic patient are caused by an acute infection.
 
Physical illness, such as hepatitis or pancreatitis, predisposes to these syndromes; delirium tremens after alcohol withdrawal is uncommon in people in good physical health.

Delirium tremors is not brought on by a gradual alcohol withdrawal. However, abrupt withdrawal may be the culprit.

questions.text:
Release of ACh is enhanced by blocking which of the following?
1. Voltage gated Na+ channel block presynaptically
2. Cl- channel block presynaptically 
3. K+ channel block presynaptically 
4. Ca2+ channel block presynaptically
questions.solution:
Blocking the potassium channels on presynaptic membrane enhances acetylcholine release. Blocking potassium channel pre-synaptically leads to depolarisation that leads to Ca++ channel opening and Ca++ ion entry that leads to release of neurotransmitters.

Acetylcholine (ACh) is a neurotransmitter that is stored in vesicles and is released when an action potential in the motor neuron opens Ca2+ channels in the presynaptic terminal. Each vesicle contains 10,000 molecules of ACh and 60 to 125 vesicles are released with each nerve impulse.

Ach diffuses across the synaptic cleft, allowing Na+ and K+ channels to open and depolarizing the muscle end plate (but not producing an action potential). Local currents in the membrane are induced by depolarization of the muscular end plate, depolarizing the membrane to the threshold and generating action potentials.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 132

questions.text: Mass drug prophylaxis is not practiced in which of the following options?
questions.solution:
Mass drug administration: This is a term for the widespread administration of medication to treat a certain ailment. Usually, it is administered in large doses to treat various diseases.
Mass treatment is not recommended for scabies by the WHO.
Scabies can be prevented by following precautions including avoiding contact with lice, maintaining personal cleanliness, and washing clothes often. Ivermectin or permethrin are used to treat scabies patients. However, the use of these medications is not done as a form of mass therapy.

questions.text: The perinatal mortality rate is governed by which of the following numerator
questions.solution:
PERINATAL MORTALITY RATE= Late Fetal Death (28 weeks gestation or more) + Early Neonatal Death (Within 7 days of life)  /(Live birth + Late Fetal Death)*1000




Perinatal mortality rate is defined as the ratio of late fetal and early neonatal deaths with birth weights greater than 1000 grams to every 1000 live births with birth weight greater than 1000 grams.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 618.

questions.text: Which among the following will be discarded in black bin according to biomedical waste management principles?
The maximum usefulness of polysaccharide vaccine 23 for streptococcal pneumonia infection is observed in which of the following options?
questions.solution:
Patients with sickle cell disease are most likely to benefit from this vaccination.
The spleen must identify capsulated organisms like  Streptococcus pneumoniae. However, sickled cells in sickle cell anemia obstruct the spleen's blood arteries, which causes splenic infraction resulting in functional asplenia(no spleen).
As a result of this asplenia, pneumococcal infection risk is enhanced. Pneumococcal vaccination (PCV-23) is therefore administered to these patients as a preventive step to lower this risk.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 228.

questions.text: Which of these is a condition depicted in flow cytometry?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hyper IgM syndrome
 
  • The given flow cytometric findings are suggestive of hyper IgM syndrome.
  • This is because B cells are positive for CD-19 on X-axis and negative for CD-40 on Y-axis when compared to normal individual.
  • Lack of CD-40 on the surface of B cells is the cause of hyper IgM syndrome.
  • In this disorder, affected patients have IgM antibodies but are deficient in IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies.
  • Mature B cells are present, but they are incapable of Ig class switching and affinity maturation, because of a defect in CD4+ helper T cells or an intrinsic B-cell defect.
  • Approximately 70% of individuals with hyper-IgM syndrome have the X-linked form of the disease, caused by mutations in the gene encoding CD40L located on Xq26 that interfere with CD4+ helper T cell function.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: Identify the function/correct option about gamma-delta T-cells from the following options-
questions.solution:
5–10% of the T cells in circulation are gamma-delta T cells, located in epithelial surfaces. They have gamma-delta heterodimer receptors, which have limited diversity and can identify phospholipid antigens, as opposed to helper and cytotoxic T cells, which have alpha-beta heterodimer receptors.
  • They differ from the conventional alpha-beta T cells by the fact that they do not require antigen processing and MHC presentation of peptides
  • They are part of innate immunity as the gamma-delta receptors exhibit limited diversity for the antigens.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: Which is the exception to the blind spot/optic disc enlargement
questions.solution:
Optic nerve hypoplasia (aka optic disc hypoplasia) does not result in blind spot/optic disc enlargement. 

POAG(primary open angle glaucoma), papilloedema and medullated nerve fibres result in enlarged blind spot. Other causes of enlarge blind spot include - Optic disc drusen, coloboma of optic disc. 

Optic nerve hypoplasia 
 

Optic nerve hypoplasia (ONH) is a congenital condition where the optic nerve is underdeveloped or smaller than normal. This leads to a reduced number of nerve fibers, which can result in visual impairment. Key features include

A. Small optic disc: The optic nerve head may appear smaller or pale compared to a normal optic disc.
"Double ring" sign is seen on fundus examination - the sign appears as a peripapillary yellowish, mottled halo that surrounds the hypoplastic(small) optic disc.

B. Visual Impairement

C. Maybe part of a syndrome (such as Septo-Optic Dysplasia) and can be associated with other abnormalities, including pituitary dysfunction, midline brain abnormalities, and endocrine disorders.
 

Other options
  • Option 1- POAG - Barring of Blind spot is one of the earliest visual field changes in POAG.
  • Option 3 - Papilledema: the blind spot enlarges as the edematous optic disc swells past its normal limits.
  • Option 4 -An improper myelination of the retinal nerve fibers results in a disorder known as medullated nerve fibres (also known as optic disc medulaltion). Beyond the lamina cribrosa, myelination continues and extends into the retina for an undetermined amount of space beyond the optic disc. The blind spot enlarges as a result of this.
Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 312, 323, 343.
Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1059.

questions.text: Which of the following is an exception to control raised IOP?

  • On the other side, dexamethasone tends to raise IOP. Corticosteroids induce IOP elevation in susceptible patients by reducing trabecular outflow facility through changes to the mechanical structure of the trabecular meshwork, extracellular matrix trabecular deposits, and reduction of trabecular endothelial functional and phagocytic activity.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1085, 1086, 1120.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a drug related to heart failure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Trimetazidine
 
  • Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidase (PFOX) inhibitor that prevents cardiac tissue from oxidizing free fatty acids (major source of ATP in heart). In order to generate ATP, the heart therefore adjusts by boosting glycolysis. Since glycolysis requires less oxygen than other metabolic processes, there is a significant reduction in myocellular oxygen demand.
  • There is no effect on determinants of myocardial O2 consumption, such as HR and BP, both at rest as well as during exercise, but angina frequency is reduced, and exercise capacity is increased.
  • Thus Trimetazidine is an anti-anginal drug and not used in heart failure.

Option 1 Nesiritide, a BNP analog that has been approved for the treatment of resistant pulmonary edema associated with acute CHF.
Option 3 Sacubitril, a neutral endopeptidase inhibitor, is approved for use in conjunction with valsartan to treat chronic CHF.
Option 4 Metoprolol if introduced gradually and maintained for long term, can retard the progression of CHF and prolong life. The benefit may result from antagonism of delete­rious effects of sympathetic overactivity (invoked reflexly by heart failure) on the myocardium.

A frequent area of questions is regarding drugs with mortality benefit in treatment of Heart failure, remember the 2 D's - Digoxin and Diuretics do not have mortality benefit in maintainance treatment of CHF. the drugs having mortality benefit in their descending order are given below, with the best being Beta blockers.
Rank Drug Class Examples
1 Beta-Blockers Bisoprolol, Carvedilol, Metoprolol Succinate
2 ARNI (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitor) Sacubitril/Valsartan 
3 ACE Inhibitors (ACEi) Enalapril, Lisinopril (if ARNI not available)
4 Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists (MRA) Spironolactone, Eplerenone
5 SGLT2 Inhibitors Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 599.

This protein is a signal-transducing component of the receptors for IL2, IL4, IL7, IL9, IL11, IL15, and IL 21

Adenosine deaminase deficiency is the primary cause of AR SCID.
  • Other Causes

Remember IL7 Receptor is most commonly mutated in SCID if nothing else is mentioned in the question, it is NOT ADA Defciency, it comes next after IL7R.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 242.

Among the given options, the correct statement is option 1- Zidovudine should not be used as monotherapy in PEP.

The recommended PEP regimes by NACO are as follows-

1. Adults and adolescents- Tenofovir 300 mg+Lamivudine 300 mg+Dolutegravir 50 mg

2. Children- Zidovudine ( dosage as per weight band ) + Lamivudine ( dosage as per weight band ) + Dolutegravir ( 50 mg )

It should be ideally started within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. 

It should be given for 4 weeks/28 days.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist used
questions.solution:
They induce ovulation, spermatogenesis, and an increase in the production of estrogen and testosterone by increasing LH/FSH release through pulsatile dosing used to treat oligospermia (male infertility), anovulation, delayed puberty, and sexual infantilism.
They reduce the synthesis of estrogen and testosterone with continuous dosing. Consequently, it is utilized to treat illnesses that depend on estrogen and testosterone, such as prostate cancer, endometritis, uterine fibroids, and ER positive breast cancer.


Reference: Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 14th edition, Page no 677, 678.

questions.text:
Assertion: A patient is admitted in a hospital for community acquired pneumonia. As a treatment, a combination therapy of Beta lactams and azithromycin is given.
Reason: This combination covers gram positive organisms and anaerobes.
questions.solution:
Beta lactams are used to treat gram-positive bacteria like pneumococcus in the case of a hospitalised patient with community-acquired pneumonia, whereas macrolides are used to treat atypical bacteria like mycoplasma, chlamydia, and legionella.

Macrolides do not cover anaerobic organisms. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 767.

questions.text: Choose the option that best describes a prucalopride-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 5HT4 Agonist
 
  • Prucalopride, a 5HT4 agonist, increases intestinal motility is licensed for the treatment of chronic constipation in females who are resistant to laxatives. It is also used in GERD and gastroparesis. Most common side effect is diarrhea.
  • Tegaserod, mosapride, and cisapride are further medications in this class.
  • Tegaserod and cisapride are banned due to the possibility of QT prolongation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 724.

choices.text: It causes peripheral neuropathy as an adverse effect
It is active against gram positive organisms

questions.text: Choose the statement that stands true to tedizolid.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) It is active against gram positive organisms
 
  • Oxazolidinidiones, such as linezolid and tedizolid, show good anti-gram-positive spectrum activity against staphylococcus, streptococcus, enterococcus, etc.

  • The oral absorption and bioavailability of linezolid and tedizolid are both good at 100% and 80%, respectively. Tedizolid is more effective against gram positive bacteria and has a longer half-life than linezolid.  Thus, linezolid is administered via the oral or intravenous route with a BD dose and tedizolid with an OD dose.

  • Linezolid is excreted primarily by kidney, whereas tedizolid by liver.
  • Because linezolid can decrease bone marrow (predominantly resulting in thrombocytopenia), it is important to monitor platelet count. Linezolid also induces mitochondrial toxicity, which manifests as peripheral neuropathy, visual neuritis, and lactic acidosis. Tedizolid causes less bone marrow suppression and does not have these negative effects.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text: Tafenoquine can be clinically used in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Tafenoquine is used for the radical cure of malaria caused by vivax and ovale. It acts on the hypnozoite stage, or exoerythrocytic tissue stage, and inhibits relapse of malaria.

Tafenoquine 300 mg is used once on the first or second day of therapy with additional medications such as chloroquine, as opposed to primaquine, which must be administered for 14 days.

It is contraindicated in pregnant and lactating females, children and G6PD deficiency. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 878.

questions.text: Identify the additional mechanism of action of tramadol apart from its regular function like all opioids, where it acts as an analgesic drug by stimulating M opioid receptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Serotonin and nor-adrenaline reuptake inhibitor

  • A synthetic codeine analogue called tramadol is used to relieve mild to moderate acute pain.
  • In an FDC format, it is combined with acetaminophen to provide analgesia.
  • As a result, it is ineffective for treating persistent or severe pain.
* It is an enantiomer racemic combination. In addition to µ receptor agonism, it is an agonist at the alpha 2 receptor and prevents serotonin and norepinephrine from being reabsorbed.
  • Dextro (+) enantiomer--- µ agonist and inhibits serotonin reuptake
  • Levo (-) enantiomer ----Alpha 2 agonist and inhibits norepinephrine reuptake

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 504.

questions.text: Identify the drug which is not given in Wilson's disease
questions.solution:
Wilson disease is a disorder of copper metabolism and is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It occurs due to mutation of gene ATP7B on chromosome 13. 

There is an excessive copper buildup in the liver, brain, and cornea (possible green-brown rings in the cornea, also known as Kayser-Fleischer rings) due to the defective incorporation of copper in ceruloplasmin. 
 
Treatment:
  • Copper-chelating agents such as Trientine or Penicillamine(option 1 and 3)
  • Lifelong maintenance therapy with Zinc. (Option 4)
  • Limited dietary copper (no organ meats, shellfish, chocolate, nuts, or mushrooms)
Calcium citrate has no role in the treatment or management of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: Identify the GPCR that does not function through opening of K+.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Angiotensin 1 receptor

M2, D2, and 5HT1 are Gi/o subtypes of GPCRs and work by opening potassium channels. In addition, the Go subtype lowers calcium while the Gi subtype lowers cyclic AMP. 

* On the other hand, the angiotensin 1 receptor is a Gq subtype of GPCR that works by raising calcium through IP3. (Phospholipase IP3/DAG activation)
  • Gs : Adenylyl cyclase activation, Ca2+channel opening
  • Gi : Adenylyl cyclase inhibition, K+ channel opening
  • Go : Ca2+ channel inhibition
  • Gq : Phospholipase C activation

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 54.

questions.text: Ciliocytopthoria is related to which disease?
questions.solution:
When an acute respiratory infection occurs, ciliocytophthoria is observed.
 
Ciliocytophthoria (CCP) is the medical term for the degeneration of ciliated cells brought on by viral infection and is a common symptom of acute respiratory infections.

questions.text: Massive blood transfusion results in -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Metabolic Acidosis
This can be controversial as both metabolic acidosis and alkalosis is possible with massive blood transfusion.
Defined as transfusion of equal blood volume of patient within in 24 hours (5L/24h) or half the blood volume within 3 hours.(2.5L/3h) 
Sodium citrate and citric acid can result in metabolic acidosis and hypocalcemia when added to blood products during storage to prevent coagulation. 

* [Extra Edge]: Complications of Massive blood transfusion
  • Hypocalcemia: ionized calcium is bound by citrate anticoagulant
  • Hyperkalemia: due to RBC breakdown
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypothermia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Initially Metabolic acidosis: due to  sodium citrate >>>Later Metabolic alkalosis due to formation of NaHCO3 from citrate, When you have to choose one choose Acidosis.
Online Reference: Jennings LK, Watson S. Massive Transfusion. [Updated 2023 Oct 29]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499929/

questions.text: How to r/o Hypothermia to an army jawan from Siachen who has been brought to an emergency department?
questions.solution:
Rectal and esophageal temperature are preferred (2 site temperature check)
Rectal temperature would be the optimum site to detect core body temperature in the clinical scenario described.
The axillary and oral temperatures are quite misleading during low or high temperatures, such in Siachen, and should not be used to gauge the core body temperature.
An infrared tympanic thermometer monitors the eardrum's temperature, which is a good indicator of body temperature overall. However, the thermometer is often improperly inserted, constructed to not penetrate deeply into the ear canal for safety reasons, or includes cerumen, which can interfere with the measurement. This is not a trustworthy way to gauge the body's core temperature.

questions.text: How is the below pressure sore graded
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Grade 4

If underlying bone or muscle is visible as shown in this image, it becomes grade 4 bed sore.

* [Extra Edge]: Stages of Pressure Sores

+ Common sites for pressure injuries and ulcers-

Ischium, Greater trochanter, Sacrum, Heel, Malleolus, Occiput.


Fig: Stages of Pressure Sores

+ Management of Pressure Ulcers:
 

Non-operative management is generally considered for patients who have a stage 1 or 2 ulcer. No conservative treatment option has proved superior to other options.

This management is quite similar to preventative management and it involved:

  • Pressure Offloading
  • Enzymatic Wound debridement
  • Wound cover using adequate dressings. No dressings has been proven to be superior than other wound dressings
  • Antibiotic cover

Non-operative debridement includes autolytic, enzymatic, larval, mechanical. These types should be considered when there is no urgent clinical need for drainage or removal of devitalized tissue. The current evidence for this is mixed.

Patients with a stage 3 and stage 4 pressure ulcer should be considered for operative management.

Absolute indications for surgical debridement include necrosis, advancing cellulitis, crepitus, fluctuance, and/or sepsis secondary to ulcer-related infection. There should be a high index of suspicion of biofilm if present >4 weeks and lacks signs of any healing in the previous 2 weeks.

The choice of reconstruction depends on location, size, and depth of the pressure sore. Each choice has benefits and limitations, as discussed below.

  • Skin Grafting: often lack sufficient bulk and strength, which results in a high failure rate.
  • Fascio cutaneous Flaps: durable, well-vascularised but limited bulk may not be sufficient for deeper wounds. For example, a rotation flap or rhomboid flap.
  • Musculocutaneous flaps: provide more depth of coverage, higher bacterial resistance.
  • Free Tissue Transfer: This has been described by is less commonly utilised.

In these cases, patients may require a bladder and/or bowel diversion.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 35.

questions.text: Which test will you do in a 10 years old boy who came with a complain of pain in right side of scrotum for past 1 hr. and you suspect torsion of testes.?
questions.solution:
Torsion in testis
  • Most prevalent in adolescents aged 10 to 25.
  • An unexpected onset of testicular pain.
  • Just after strenuous exercises. (Example sexual activity).
  • "Bell Clapper deformity" is a significant risk factor.
  • The investigation of choice: Color Doppler detects the reduced blood flow to the testis in torsion
  • Manipulation can be used to correct torsion in the first hour, but afterwards surgery is required to fix the testis.
  • If the problem cannot be resolved by manipulation or if more than an hour has passed, surgery must be performed. The procedure MUST be completed in 4 hours or else the testis will undergo infarction. 
  • Because the anatomical variation causing the torsion is probably bilateral, orchidopexy should be performed on both the affected and unaffected testicles to prevent further torsion in the other testis. 
  • Differential diagnosis:  epididym-orchitis 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 254.

questions.text: What is the intervention in an anorexia patient who is on a steady diet plan ,eating her meals but still her weight remains unchanged for a week?
questions.solution:
Because food may be often regurgitated after meals, keep an eye on the patient for two hours after eating. Anorexic patients are obsessed with their weight, their body image, and looking slim. It is most frequently linked to obsessive-compulsive personality characteristics. There are two major subtypes of it:
Restricting type: Loses weight by diet, fasting, and/or vigorous exercise; does not regularly indulge in binge-eating or purging behavior.
Eating binges followed by self-induced vomiting, laxatives, enemas, or the use of diuretics are examples of the binge-eating/purging type.

questions.text: What is the  likely abnormality in a patient with renal failure who develops vomiting in ICU and ABG performed shows pH = 7.40. PaCO2 = 40, HCO3 = 24, Anion gap = 21?
questions.solution:
The likely metabolic abnormality in this patient is high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis. 
 
  • Patients with renal failure may have metabolic acidosis and associated vomiting in this patient may cause metabolic alkalosis. However, the parameters of arterial blood gas analysis appear to be normal. This disparity raises the suspicion of a mixed acid-base disorder. 
  • When metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis coexist in the same patient, pH may be in the normal range. In such cases, the presence of an elevated anion gap denotes the presence of metabolic acidosis. 
  • AG is high, which points to high AG metabolic acidosis. 
  • In high anion gap metabolic acidosis, excess H+ ions are buffered by bicarbonate and the bicarbonate level falls. The fall in HCO3- is expected to be equal to the rise in anion gap. The difference between the rise in anion gap and the fall in HCO3- (delta gap) is zero in simple HAGMA. 
  • Associated vomiting in this patient results in loss of acid and hence the fall of bicarbonate level is less compared to the rise in the anion gap. A delta gap of more than +6 indicates the presence of additional metabolic alkalosis. 
    In this case, the delta gap is 10, which points to metabolic alkalosis in addition to high AG metabolic acidosis. 
  • Delta gap = (Actual anion gap - Normal anion gap) -(Normal bicarbonate - Actual bicarbonate) 
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same
 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359-361.

questions.text: Renal feed for CKD patients
questions.solution:
A low-volume diet is preferred to prevent toxic protein degradation byproduct accumulation, sodium and volume overload, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia.
 
In order to reduce the patient's risk of malnutrition and wasting associated with ESRD, a high-calorie feed is preferred.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2313, 2317.

questions.text:
Renopulmonary syndrome includes
a. Good pasture syndrome
b. Leptospira
c. Hantavirus
d. Wegener's granulomatosis
questions.solution:
All of the given options produce renopulmonary symptoms. 

Pulmonary renal syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition defined as the combination of diffuse alveolar haemorrhage (DAH) and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
 
  • Leptospirosis: The classic presentation, often referred to as Weil’s syndrome, encompasses the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Patients die of septic shock with multiorgan failure and/or severe bleeding complications that most commonly involve the lungs (pulmonary hemorrhage).
  • Hantavirus infection: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome causes myocardial depression and increased pulmonary vascular permeability.
 

  • Differential diagnoses of pulmonary renal syndrome

    ANCA-associated vasculitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
    Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)
    Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA)
    Anti-GBM disease Anti-GBM disease (Good Pasture syndrome)
    ANCA-negative vasculitis IgA disease
    Cryoglobulinaemia
    Drug-induced vasculitis Cocaine
    d-penicillamine
    Autoimmune connective tissue disease Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
    Polymyositis
    Diabetes mellitus
    Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)
    Systemic sclerosis



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 980, 1420.

questions.text: Which hormone will not have to be additionally supplied in case of a 56 years old female who underwent trans sphenoid hypophysectomy for pituitary tumor and now has low ACTH, TSH, FSH and LH

questions.text: A patient with deafness, hematuria and CKD. Light microscopy of urine is normal. Maternal Uncle has similar disease. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome presents with triad of deafness (SNHL), hematuria, and anterior lenticonus. It also lead to Chronic Kidney disease.
 
  • Classically, patients with Alport’s syndrome develop hematuria, thinning and splitting of the GBMs, and mild proteinuria (<1–2 g/24 h), which appears late in the course, followed by chronic glomerulosclerosis leading to renal failure in association with sensorineural deafness.
  • Some patients develop lenticonus of the anterior lens capsule, “dot and fleck” retinopathy, and rarely, leiomyomatosis.
  • Approximately 85% of patients with Alport’s syndrome have an X-linked inheritance of mutationsin the α5(IV) collagen chain on chromosome Xq22–24.

Other options: 
 
  • Thin basement membrane disease does not include deafness or chronic kidney disease.
  • Goodpasture syndrome and PSGN are ruled out by conventional light microscopy.
  • Initially, kidney biopsy specimens examined through light microscopy may be normal in alport syndrome.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2346, 2347.

choices.text: Normal pH can not rule out acid base disorder
Choose another site if Allen test is abnormal
Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood

questions.text: What is not true regarding ABG sampling?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 3. Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood
Syringe should be flushed with heparin and not added/loaded.
 
  • Normal pH, HCO3, and PCO2 levels may not indicate absence of an acid-base imbalance: This statement is true. While normal values of pH, bicarbonate (HCO3), and partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) may suggest a balanced acid-base state, they do not guarantee the absence of an acid-base imbalance. There are different types of acid-base disorders, such as respiratory acidosis/alkalosis and metabolic acidosis/alkalosis, which can exist even with normal pH, HCO3, and PCO2 values. Additional parameters and the evaluation of compensatory mechanisms are required to make an accurate assessment of acid-base balance.
  • A different site should be tried if modified Allen's test is negative: This statement is true. The modified Allen's test is performed to assess collateral circulation in the hand before arterial puncture. If the modified Allen's test is negative (indicating inadequate collateral circulation), it is recommended to try a different arterial site for blood sampling to avoid potential complications, such as hand ischemia.
  • Radial artery is the preferred site: This statement is true. The radial artery is commonly preferred for arterial blood gas (ABG) sampling due to its accessibility and lower risk of complications compared to other sites. It is easily palpable and provides a relatively comfortable experience for patients.



Reference: Trulock EP III. Arterial Blood Gases. In: Walker HK, Hall WD, Hurst JW, editors. Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations. 3rd edition. Boston: Butterworths; 1990. Chapter 49. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK371/

WHO Guidelines on Drawing Blood: Best Practices in Phlebotomy. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2010. Annex I, Modified Allen test. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK138652/

questions.text: What is not true about the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Thrombocytopenia is rather in indication for performing bone marrow biopsy. 
 
 CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR BM BIOPSY
  • Hemorrhagic disorders such DIC, concurrent anticoagulant usage, and congenital coagulation factor deficits (such as hemophilia).
  • The most frequent and dangerous occurrence is bleeding, especially in thrombocytopenic patients and those taking aspirin, warfarin, or heparin.
  • In these patients, a BMA or BMTB should only be performed if it is absolutely necessary. If this is the case, factor replacement or stopping anticoagulation should be considered before the surgery, and the patient should be thoroughly watched for 24 hours afterward. BMA is not contraindicated in cases of severe thrombocytopenia as long as the site is kept under pressure for an extended period of time to stop bleeding.
  •  When a bone marrow biopsy is recommended for obese individuals with severe thrombocytopenia, it is better to administer a platelet transfusion to increase the platelet count to > 15 x 10^9/L.
  • Other potential issues include persistent discomfort, a fracture (related to osteoporosis), and damage to nearby structures (such as damage to arteries).
  • At the sampling site, there may be skin infections or recent radiation therapy.
Reference: 
Rindy LJ, Chambers AR. Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy. [Updated 2023 May 29]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559232/

questions.text:
Which of the following is done in atonic PPH ?
a. Uterine massage is given. 
b. Ergometrine IV is administered to all
c. B-Lynch suture, if medical management fails
d. Suction of uterus
questions.solution:
• Uterine massage is given in atonic PPH. However, it is not the first step, first step is medical management.
  • Ergometrine is given IM not IV

STEPS OF MANAGEMENT

Medical Management:
Uterotonic medications are provided after an atonic PPH diagnosis in order to raise uterine tone.
Misoprostol (PGEI), methyl ergometrine and oxytocin infusion given quickly:
Mechanical Method: If the medical approach fails, try the mechanical approach.
Bimanual compression and/or massage: Bimanual uterine compression must begin right away to control atonic postpartum haemorrhage and may need to last for 20 to 30 minutes or longer.
Uterine packing:
Balloon Tamponade: Condom catheter, Sengstaken-Blakemore esophageal catheter, or Bakri balloon catheter are all options for balloon tamponade.
Surgical Techniques: If the aforementioned management techniques don't work, think about surgery.
B-Lynch suture.
Uterine artery ligation: 90% of the blood flow to the uterus during pregnancy comes from the uterine arteries, which are tied off. In 75–90% of cases, direct ligation of these conveniently located vessles can successfully reduce haemorrhage.
Internal iliac artery ligation.
Radiographic embolization of pelvic vessels
Hysterectomy: definite method.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 777-779.

questions.text: From where is the marked structure derived ?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the provided specimen is membranous part of the interventricular spectrum, which is generated from the endocardial cushion.

DEVELOPMENT OF INTERVENTRICULAR SEPTUM

The muscular interventricular (IV) septum which has developed from the floor of the primitive atrium in the midline grows toward the fused AV cushions.
Until 7th week, there is the presence of a crescent-shaped interventricular foramen
between the free edge of the interventricular septum and the fused endocardial cushions.
The membranous IV septum closes the IV foramen.
This happens by the end of 7th week due to the fusion of bulbar ridges and the endocardial cushion.
The right bulbar ridge, the left bulbar ridge and the endocardial cushion
fuse to form membranous part of interventricular septum.
The membranous part of the interventricular septum is derived from an extension of tissue from the right side of the endocardial cushion to the muscular part of the septum as well as neural crest cells.

 

 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 194,197,199,200

questions.text: Which of the following will you not do in a patient having massive hematemesis
questions.solution:
Platelet transfusion is NOT done in case of active variceal bleeding unless definite coagulopathy is documented. It is indicated only when Platelet count is < 50,000/microL or in patients with evidence of micro vascular bleeding.
 
  • Bleeding Esophageal Varices: The most frequent location for variceal haemorrhage is the lower oesophagus. The risk of bleeding of esophageal varices increases above 12 mm of Hg. It is a medical emergency. Those who have severe bleeding should be admitted to the intensive care unit.
 
  • Management Blood transfusions, colloids, and plasma expanders should all be used to reduce the blood volume. Rectify coagulopathy: Vitamin K (10 mg intravenously) is given, but fresh-frozen plasma must also be given to correct a coagulopathy (FFP). Esophageal balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube): Four lumens are present in modified Sengstaken-Blakemore (old Sengstaken-Blakemore tube contains 3 tubes). One for esophageal balloon dilation, one for stomach aspiration, one for gastric balloon dilation, and one for esophageal aspiration.
 
  • Pharmacotherapy:  Somatostatin and octreotide, which are long-acting analogues of the hormone, are effective. Previously used vasopressin is also useful, but nitroglycerin must be administered in addition to it to prevent constriction of the coronary vessels. Terlipressin has recently become widely used to stop bleeding.
 
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunts (TIPSS) is an intrahepatic shunt done as definitive management of Esophageal varices. Urgent Endoscopy is also indicated. Studies have demonstrated that a lower rate of rebleeding and shorter length of hospital stay when endoscopy was performed within 24 hours of admission.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1203.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page no 274.

questions.text: In a 24 year old female who underwent lateral skull base surgery presented with complaints of recurrent aspirations. There is no change in patient voice. Do you think that most likely there has been a nerve injury during surgery?
questions.solution:
The nerve injured in the given clinical scenario is SLN.

The superior laryngeal nerve bifurcates into internal and external laryngeal nerve. 

The internal laryngeal nerve supplies sensory innervation to mucosa above vocal cords and therefore, injury of SLN via internal laryngeal nerve will result in recurrent aspirations. 
 
The external laryngeal nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle. In SLN injury, only cricothyroid muscle will be injured which will lead to loss of vocalization of only high pitch sounds. It will not result in loss of voice since remaining muscles of vocalization are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text:
Match the following options
1. Marfans syndrome                
2. Osteogenesis imperfect        
3. Klippel fiel syndrome            
4. Neurofibromatosis
questions.solution:
Osteogenesis imperfecta symptoms include floppy joints, brittle bones, deafness, blue sclera, and a propensity to get better with age. The epiphysis is bulbous, and the bone is short and thin. Bodies of vertebrates are biconcave.
 
A congenital musculoskeletal condition called Klippel-Feil syndrome is characterized by the fusion of at least two neck vertebrae. Short necks, low hairlines at the back of the head, and limited movement of the upper spine are the characteristics of Klippel-Feil syndrome that are most frequently observed.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition brought on by an elastin and collagen defect. The most prevalent clinical characteristics are being tall with disproportionately long legs, having long fingers, having scoliosis, a high arched palate, chest abnormalities, and having generalized joint laxity.

Neurofibromatosis type 1 is characterized by cafe au lait macules, optic nerve glioma, sphenoid bone dysplasia, tibial pseudoarthrosis, axillary/inguinal freckling, multiple neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibroma, irish nodules. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner and caused due to mutation in neurofibomin gene on chromosome number 17.

questions.text: The exception to the administration of Anti D prophylaxis from the following conditions is-
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Intra uterine transfusion at 28 weeks
 
  • The anti-D vaccine is not administered during intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks of pregnancy. Intrauterine transfusion is performed in alloimmunized pregnancies, where the maternal immune system (Rh negative) has been exposed to Rh-positive fetal blood.
 
  • The purpose of the anti-D vaccine is to prevent the formation of maternal antibodies against fetal red blood cells, which is already happening in alloimmunized pregnancies. Thus, anti-D vaccine administration is only appropriate for ICT-negative, non-isoimmunized pregnancies.
 
  • Intrauterine transfusion is considered when the peak systolic velocity of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) >1.5 MoM, when hydrops develops, or when fetal hematocrit levels are critically low. In these cases, the mother already has antibodies against the fetal red blood cells, making anti-D vaccination unnecessary.

Indications for administering anti-D include:

- Pregnancy loss: spontaneous or elective abortion, and ectopic pregnancy.
- Fetal death: at any stage of pregnancy.
- Procedures: such as amniocentesis, chorionic villus sampling, fetal blood sampling, and molar pregnancy evacuation.
- Other situations: antepartum bleeding (including threatened abortion), delivery (vaginal or cesarean), external cephalic version, placental abruption, manual removal of the placenta, and abdominal trauma during pregnancy.

All Rh D-negative women should receive a single dose of 300 mcg of anti-D at 28 weeks of pregnancy, provided that the ICT is negative.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 354-357.

questions.text:
From the given options choose the most appropriate one Case A primigravida 37 weeks period of gestation diagnosed to be having a transverse lie:
1. Rpt USG to confirm the lie
2. Do L/s at the onset of labour
3. During L/s deliver by breach
4. Transverse lie is (MC) associated with placenta previa
5. Admit at 36 weeks

A. 1- False 2- True 3- False 4-True 5-False
B. 1- False 2- True 3-True 4- False 5- True
C. 1- True 2- True 3- True 4- False 5- False
D. 1- False 2- True 3- False 4- True 5- False
questions.solution:
Transverse lie: When the fetus' longitudinal axis is perpendicular to the uterus' long axis, this is referred to as a transverse lie. The shoulder is typically placed above the pelvic inlet when lying transversely.
 
Transverse Lie Management During Pregnancy
A patient with transverse lie who is in active labour should typically have a caesarean delivery.

Without using anaesthetic, the External Cephalic Version method externally rotates the foetus from breech presentation to cephalic presentation.

Cesarean Section
In this operation, incisions are made in the uterine and anterior abdominal walls of the mother to deliver the foetus. If the foetus is in the transverse position, a low transverse incision into the uterus may make foetal extraction challenging since neither its feet nor its head occupy the lower uterine section. Hence, vertical hysterotomy is indicated.

questions.text: Where is intrinsic and extrinsic pathway seen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Apoptosis

Apoptosis can occur via an intrinsic or extrinsic pathway.
  1. The intrinsic pathway involves the release of cytochrome C from the inner surface of the mitochondria and release of SMAC/DIABLO from mitochondria.
  2. The extrinsic pathway is activated by TRAIL and Fas Ligand (which binds to CD95-Fas). The initiator caspase in the mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway is caspase 9 while in extrinsic pathway is caspase 8 and 10.
Option 3 Necroptosis- this form of cell death is a hybrid that shares aspects of both necrosis and apoptosis. Morphologically, and to some extent biochemically, it resembles necrosis, as both are characterized by loss of ATP, swelling of the cell and organelles, generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), release of lysosomal enzymes, and ultimately rupture of the plasma membrane.
Option 4 Pyroptosis- this is a form of apoptosis that is accompanied by the release of the fever-inducing cytokine IL-1.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 45.

questions.text: The image reflects which sign
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2: Sea shore sign.

questions.text: Which of these produces vWF

A 24-year-old lady presented with abdominal pain and was treated with some medication. 3 hours post-treatment with this medication - the lady developed palpitations and respiratory distress. Vitals were stable and ECG is shown below. Treatment?
questions.solution:
Torsade de pointes is the suspected diagnosis based on the patients' ECG.
 
Long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that result in Torsade de pointes can be effectively treated and prevented with IV MgSO4.
 
  • Defibrillation should be started right away if the patient is unstable.

    The ECG presented indicates wide QRS complex tachycardia with varying QRS amplitudes, suggesting torsades de pointes. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, the preferred treatment is intravenous MgSO₄.

  • Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) is characterized by continuously changing QRS morphology. When it occurs in individuals with congenital or acquired QT interval prolongation, it is known as torsades de pointes. Patients may experience near-syncope, syncope, or cardiac arrest.
  • IV MgSO₄ is very effective for both treating and preventing recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that can trigger torsades de pointes.
  • If magnesium treatment is ineffective, an infusion of isoproterenol or pacing at a rate of 100-120 depolarizations per minute generally suppresses VT recurrences. In cases where the patient is hemodynamically unstable, immediate defibrillation is necessary.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1911, 1923, 1924.

questions.text: Mast cells are activated by?
questions.solution:
Mast cells are activated by the cross-linking of high-affinity IgE receptors, as are their circulating counterparts, basophils.
Mast cells can also be activated by a variety of different factors, such as complements C5a and C3a, which work by binding to receptors on the mast cell membrane and are known as anaphylatoxins because they generate reactions that resemble anaphylaxis.

Some chemokines, such as IL-8, as well as medications like codeine and morphine, adenosine, and melittin (found in bee venom), are additional mast cell secretagogues.

Molecules/Cytokines functioning as Mast cell secretagogues
  • C3a
  • C5a
  • IL- 8
  • Codeine
  • Morphine
  • Adenosine
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infections in post transplant patients?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1. CMV (Cytomegalovirus).

Cytomegalovirus is the most common cause of infection in post-transplant patients due to immunosuppression required to prevent graft rejection. CMV infection can cause a wide range of complications, including pneumonitis, hepatitis, gastrointestinal disease, and CMV syndrome, which presents with fever, malaise, and leukopenia.

Other options

  • Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) can cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) but is not the most common post-transplant infection.
  • Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause shingles due to reactivation, but it is less common than CMV.
  • BK virus primarily affects renal transplant patients, leading to BK virus nephropathy, but it is not as common as CMV infection overall.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 479.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is incorrect regarding steps followed during the biopsy of metastatic bone tumor infiltration?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, option A is the incorrect one.
  • After carefully planning the biopsy site and approach using X-Rays or CT scan, smallest longitudinal incision and not transverse should be used to obtain the sample.
  • This is because a wider resection of soft tissue maybe required in transverse resection at the time of definitive surgery. 

Option B- Specimen should be taken not just from one plane. 

Option C- Specimen should be taken after radiological investigations. This is because minor bleed at the biopsy site can distort imaging findings if biopsy is done before imaging.

Option D- Sample is taken from the periphery of the lesion due to frequent presence of central necrosis. This is due to the fact that tumor receives its blood supply from blood vessels arranged peripherally around the tumor. Hence, the central portion of the tumor is more prone to undergo ischemic necrosis, especially if the tumor has a high turnover where it outgrows its blood supply. 


Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 617

questions.text: What is ETDRS done for ?
questions.solution:
A randomized clinical trial called the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) investigated the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema.
The study's findings showed that focal photocoagulation has a positive impact on diabetic macular edema.
The ETDRS study significantly influenced the management of diabetic retinopathy and diabetic macular edema, establishing laser photocoagulation as a standard treatment and paving the way for further studies on anti-VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor) therapies in diabetic eye disease.
Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) and recent anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) clinical trials results are applied in the management of diabetic macular edema or neovascularization which has reduced the risk of severe visual loss to less than 5%.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 543.

questions.text:
Malarial Vector indices is included in which of the following
a. Human blood index
b. Biting density 
c. Slide positivity rate
d. Inoculation rate
questions.solution:
Malarial Vector indices
 
  • The average number of anopheline bites per day per person is known as the man biting rate (biting density). Standardized vector catch on human bait is used to determine it.
  • The percentage of female anopheles with one sporozoite in their saliva is known as the sporozoite rate.
  • Inoculation rate: This is calculated by multiplying the rate of man-biting by the rate of infectious sporozoites.
  • The percentage of freshly fed female anopheline mosquitoes whose stomachs contain human blood is known as the human blood index. It reveals the anthrophilism's level.
  • Mosquito density: This term is typically represented as the quantity of mosquitoes caught per hour of labour.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 307.

questions.text: Which is not true for influenza virus
questions.solution:
Secondary attack rate is 5 to 15%: This statement refers to the percentage of people who become infected after being exposed to an infected individual.
  • For influenza, the secondary attack rate typically ranges from 10% to 30%, so this statement is generally accurate.
 
  • 1 to 5 years is a high-risk age group: Young children, particularly those aged 6 months to 5 years, are considered a high-risk group for severe influenza complications. This statement is accurate.
 
  • Virus shedding present before the patient presents with symptoms: Influenza virus shedding can begin 1-2 days before symptoms appear, which is why the virus is highly contagious even before symptoms manifest. This statement is accurate.
 
  • Aquatic birds are reservoirs: Aquatic birds, particularly wild ducks and shorebirds, are indeed the natural reservoirs of influenza A viruses. This statement is accurate.
Given this analysis, all the statements are true, except for the potential nuance in the secondary attack rate, which might vary slightly depending on the context. However, the generally accepted secondary attack rate range for influenza does fall within the 5% to 15% range.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 172.

Additionally, the Sample Registration System (SRS) also plays a role in gathering mortality data, but the direct recording of causes is primarily through medical certification.

questions.text: Match the following options-
Which drug can be used to reduce ammonia levels in Urea cycle d/o?
questions.solution:
Phenylbutyrate lowers ammonia levels by directing urea into a different pathway. Thus, acting as an ammonia scavenger. Additional drugs (ammonia scavengers) that can be used to produce the same result include:
Phenylacetate and benzoate- By administering IV phenylacetate and benzoate, which bind to glutamine and glycine, respectively, to form phenylacetylglutamine and hippuric acid, which are eliminated in urine, excess nitrogen can be removed.
Arginine- Arginine is an essential amino acid that must be administered intravenously in order to restart protein synthesis, expect arginine deficiency.
IV Glucose- In order to prevent catabolism and the formation of ammonia, lipid infusion and intravenous glucose are the main treatments for urea cycle disorders in patients who are unconscious.

questions.text: What is the management in case of a person taking 60,000 IU of vitamin D for long time, which lead to Vitamin D toxicity
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 2) Glucocorticoid

The use of glucocorticoid (Dexamethasone, prednisolone, etc.) therapy will lower plasma calcium levels by inhibiting the action of vitamin D (1,25D), which leads to decreased intestinal calcium absorption and increased urine calcium excretion. Loss of osteoid (decreased formation and increased resorption) indirectly results in loss of Ca2+ from bone, producing negative calcium balance.

Other medications like chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are less effective in treating hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 309.

questions.text: What is the significance of giving glycopyrrolate before General anesthesia ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) \(\downarrow\)se secretions
  • Glycopyrrolate is used to reduce salivary, tracheobronchial, and pharyngeal secretions before anesthesia, as an antispasmodic, to reduce drooling in Parkinson's disease patients, and to prevent the cholinergic effects of neostigmine, which is used to reverse the effects of muscle relaxants, after surgery.
  • Neostigmine 0.5–2.0 mg (30–50 µg/kg) i.v., preceded by atropine or glycopyrrolate 10 µg/kg to block muscarinic effects, rapidly reverses muscle paralysis induced by competitive neuromuscular blockers.

* [Extra Edge]: Preanesthetic medication
  • When irritant general anesthetics (ether) were used, prior administration of anticholinergics (atropine, hyoscine, glycopyrrolate) was imperative to check increased salivary and tracheobronchial secretions.
  • However, with current use of nonirritating anesthetics (halothane, etc.) the requirement has decreased, though atropine may still be employed because halothane sensitizes the heart to NA mediated ventricular arrhythmias which are especially prone to occur during vagal slowing.
  • Atropinic drugs also prevent laryngospasm, not by an action on laryngeal muscles, which are skeletal muscles, but by reducing respiratory secretions that reflexly predispose to laryngo­spasm.
  • Vasovagal attack during anesthesia can also be prevented.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 130.

questions.text:
Assertion: In intubation, extensions of neck and flexion of head is favourable. 
Reason: Jaw thrust removes tongue from the posterior pharyngeal wall
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Assertion is false but reason is true
 
  • If there is no indication of cervical spine instability, a head-tilt-chin-lift should be done first. The most frequent cause of airway obstruction is posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis.
  • The patient's head is tilted (extended) with pressure from one hand's palm, and the chin is raised with the forefinger and index finger of the other hand.
  • The Jaw-thrust, which is carried out by placing both hands on either side of the patient's head, grabbing the angles of the jaw, and raising, may be more efficient in opening the airway (lifts the tongue from posterior pharyngeal wall).
  • Patient is given “morning air sniffing” position (Chevalier Jackson position) i.e. extension at atlanto-occipital joint and flexion of neck (atlanto axial joint) by keeping a pillow below the neck. This position brings the oral, pharyngeal and laryngeal axis in one line thus facilitating the visualization of vocal cords on direct laryngoscopy

questions.text: A gentleman 24 years of age with h/o of hemophilia and the current bleeding episode was treated with two units of FFP since cryoprecipitate and factor VIII concentrate are unavailable. 2 hours post-transfusion revealed B/L crepitations and Xray chest showed B/L infiltrates. JVP is normal, BP is slightly decreased. What's the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario - the patient developed new-onset respiratory distress, and B/L Crepitations within 2 hours of FFP transfusion. This is most likely due to TRALI.
 
  • Given that TRALI frequently occurs with plasma components, especially following FFP/Platelets and the JVP is normal with slightly decreased -the diagnosis is likely to be TRALI. (option 1).
  • TRALI usually occurs within six hours after the transfusion and is accompanied by a new ALI (acute lung injury) ± hemodynamic compromise. The management is supportive.
 
  • Since the patient is young, free of cardio-renal disease, and has a normal JVP, and low BP, it is unlikely that they have TACO. In TACO, patients frequently have hypertension and high JVP.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 891, 894.

questions.text: A person admitted to the cardiac failure ward for heart transplant also has a compromised renal function. 6hrs post blood transfusion developed chest tightness, dyspnoea, BP=160/94 mm Hg, and elevated JVP. What is the probable Dx?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis in the above scenario is TACO i.e. Transfusion associated Circulatory overload. The respiratory distress, elevated blood pressure, compromised renal function, and elevated JVP point all point towards TACO. 

Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload(TACO)

Etiopathogenesis
An increase in hydrostatic pressure due to an increase in pulmonary blood volume (due to transfusion) and central venous pressure results in fluid extravasation into the alveolar space leading to pulmonary edema/hypoxia/respiratory distress.

Clinical Features
1. Characterized by respiratory distress, hypoxia, B/L Rales Along with Hypertension/elevated JVP. 
2. Does not have a fever, ejection fraction is reduced, and CXR shows B/L infiltrate. 

Management
1. Supportive
2. Diuretics
 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 891, 895.

questions.text:
Proto-oncogene to Oncogene transformation occurs by:
a. Point mutation
b. Promoter initiation
c. Amplification
d. Enhancer insertion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) a, b, c and d are correct

* Oncogenes can develop from proto-oncogenes through the following mechanisms:
  • Proto-oncogene point mutations, deletions, or insertions that result in increased transcription.
  • Gene amplification processes that result in extra proto-oncogene chromosomal copies.
  • Chromosomal translocations that result in the fusion of a proto-oncogene with a different gene to create a fusion protein with cancer-causing properties.
  • Insertion mutagenesis: Both the promoter and enhancer regions result in an increase in gene function. C-Myc amplification by oncogenic viruses is the best example.
               
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 324.

d. Central field defect s/i in open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
Option A- Latanoprost is a PGF 2 alpha analogue and should be used with caution in a patient of bronchial asthma. 
 
Option B- Secondary angle closure, which resembles acute angle closure glaucoma, has been linked to Topiramate.
When angle closure manifests bilaterally, there should be an increased suspicion of medication-induced angle closure glaucoma.

Option C- Dorzolamide is an inhibitor of carbonic anhydrase and is seen to reduce ocular blood flow in the long run.

questions.text: Superior semicircular dehiscence presents with all except :
questions.solution:
The Tullio phenomenon is observed in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS), while sensorineural hearing loss is not seen. The vestibular activation brought on by sound or pressure is referred to as the Tullio phenomenon. Conductive Hearing Loss is seen in SCC dehisense. Patients report feeling dizzy as a result of pressure or noise. Some people might exhibit persistent imbalances. The patient adopts a noise avoidance strategy. Some people may also have hyperacusis or gaze-evoked tinnitus.

Reference : https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3578588/#:~:text=Results%20and%20Conclusions%20Symptoms%20of,Tullio%20phenomenon)%2C%20among%20others

questions.text:
What will be the volume of lung remaining, if the chest wall recoil is eliminated
1, Residual volume
2. Functional residual capacity
3. Zero
4. Minimal volume
questions.solution:
If the chest wall recoil (expanding force) does not counteract the lung's elastic recoil (collapsing force), the lung will collapse to minimal lung volume (which is lower than residual volume).

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 619,620

questions.text: What is the probable Dx in case where a 28 year old man who has recently finished a half marathon,complains of pain along the anterior and medial aspect of the tibia which increases on jogging and walking for a long time and his X-ray was found to be (N).
questions.solution:
• Shin splints, also known as MTSS (medial Tibial Stress syndrome), are a painful condition of the anterior compartment of the leg along the thin bone (tibia) brought on by swollen muscles in the anterior compartment, particularly the tibialis anterior muscle, as a result of athletic overexertion.
  • Shin splints may be a mild form of anterior compartment syndrome.
  • Exercise-induced discomfort at the distal two-thirds of the medial tibial border, pain triggered during or after physical activity, and a normal X-ray are all characteristics that point to the diagnosis.
  • IOC- MRI

Reference- Campbell’s operative orthopaedics 14 Edition Page no 2486

questions.text:
Match the following 
a. Gunstock                      i) Cubitus varus 
b. Button hole deformity ii) Rheumatoid arthritis
c. Haglund's deformity    iii) Calcaneum
d. Madelung  deformity   iv) Wrist 

A. a-ii b-i c-iii d- iv
B. a-iii b-ii c-i d-iv
C. a-iv b-i c-ii d-iii
D. a- i b- ii c- iii d- iv
questions.solution:
A deviation of the distal radial epiphysis known as Madelung's deformity causes a progressive ulnar and volar tilt to arise at the distal radial articular surface.
 
Posterosuperior calcaneal exostosis is a Haglund deformity.

Boutonniere deformity (Button hole): Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and flexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP).

Gunstock deformity, also known as Cubitus varus deformity and malunited supracondylar fracture of the humerus.
•  Madelung- Volar ulnar deviation
•  Haglund deformity - Abnormal prominence on calcaneum
•  Button hole deformity: Rheumatoid arthritis
•   Gunstock deformity -cubitus varus

Used in resuscitation of a normal baby
In the delivery room for assessment of the mother

questions.text: All of the following are uses of the given instrument EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• A neonatal pulse oximeter attached to lower limb is displayed in the image.
  • It is used for delivery room assessment of neonate, not mother (option 4). 
Applications/Uses of pulse oximeter
  1. Checking for endotracheal tube placement and the efficiency of the bag and mask ventilation.
  2. Detecting cyanosis (in CCHD like TOF) (option 2)
  3. Monitoring for hypoxia during suction and laryngoscopy.
  4. Monitoring for apnea (Indicating bradycardia and desaturation) - (option 1)
  5. It can be used in addition to Allen's test to determine the potency of the ulnar artery.
  6. It aids in the assessment of the body's response to resuscitation. (option 3)


Reference - Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics, Edition 21st , Page No 588

questions.text: After initial steps in neonatal resuscitation, if H.R. < 100 which of the following is NOT done?
questions.solution:
According to NRP, after the initial steps of resuscitation, if a child is apneic or gasping or having HR<100 - Immediately start PPV(option 3), attach SpO2 monitor(option 2) and attach cardiac monitor(ECG) (option 4)

CPAP (option 1) can be considered in case of respiratory distress(laboured breathing or cyanosis) if HR>100, not when HR<100. Its not done when the neonates' HR<100. 





Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition , Page no 128

questions.text: What is seen on the wound surface in a bullet wipe
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. debris from the barrel

Bullet wipe: The dark area that surrounds a bullet hole and can be used to identify the entry point (as opposed to an exit site).
  • The bullet wipe, which is commonly generated by lubrication, lead, dirt in the bore, and discharge residues, is a deposition of different residues around the entrance defect at different ranges found on the clothing of bullet injury victims.
  • It aids in detecting the wounds on the body's inlet and outlet.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 237.

questions.text: What causes the detachment of myosin head
questions.solution:
ATP attachment cause Myosin head separation from the actin filament. myosin complex stays attached to actin until another ATP molecule attaches and starts a new cycle.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the ECG shown below. The patient complains of palpitation and dizziness
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with absent p waves and irregularly spaced R-R intervals, diagnostic of Atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Option 2- PSVT will have regularly spaced R-R interval with narrow QRS complex tachycardia and absent p waves.
  • Option 3- 2nd degree heart block will be characterized by progressively increasing PR interval followed by missing of a QRS complex.
  • Option 4- MI will produce significant elevation of ST segment with reciprocal changes in opposite leads.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1903, 1904.

questions.text: How to manage a patient who was given ampicillin 2g I/V and after that, the person developed rash on skin, hypotension and difficulty in breathing
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 0.5 ml of 1:1000 adrenaline by IM route
 
  • Rashes, hypotension, and breathing problems are signs of ampicillin-induced anaphylaxis. In anaphylaxis, epinephrine 0.3–0.5 ml intramuscularly at a dilution of 1:1000 is the preferred medication (0.3-0.5 mg).
  • Only in severe anaphylactic shock should intravenous epinephrine 2.5 ml at 1:10,000 (0.25 mg) be administered. Steroids, bronchodilators, and antihistaminics are further supportive medications used in anaphylaxis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 97.
