questions.text: Which of these best describes the mechanism of 'vasopressin escape' in SIADH
questions.solution:
Vasopressin escape occurs due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 receptors. In SIADH, prolonged exposure to anti-diuretic hormone results in downregulation of aquaporin 2 receptors. This maintains euvolemic status of the body and doesn't lead to dilutional hyponatremia by preventing excessive reabsorption of water despite high levels of ADH. This phenomenon is known as vasopressin escape.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 688

choices.text: It has a Complete response to tyrosine kinase inhibitor in all cases

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the accelerated phase of CML
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 1) It has a Complete response to tyrosine kinase inhibitor in all cases

According to 5th edition of WHO classification of hematolymphoid tumors, accelerated phase of CML is removed.
Criteria for blastic phase includes-
1. Presence of >20% myeloid blasts in blood or bone marrow
2. Presence of extramedullary proliferation of blasts.
3. Presence of increased lymphoblasts in peripheral blood or bone marrow

The presence of more than or equal to 1 of the following cytogenetic/hematological criteria or provisional criteria for response to tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) therapy defines CML-AP.
Hematological/Cytogenetic Criteria:
A persistent or increasing high WBC count that is therapy-unresponsive (>10 x 10^9/L).
Splenomegaly that persists or worsens and is unresponsive to treatment.
Unresponsive to therapy, persistent thrombocytosis (>1000 x 10^9/L) Persistent (<100 x 10^9/L) thrombocytopenia unrelated to treatment. >20% basophils in the PBS 10-19% blasts in PBS Philadelphia (Ph) chromosome.

Patients in accelerated or blastic phase may receive therapy with TKIs, preferably second- or third-generation TKIs (dasatinib, nilotinib, bosutinib, ponatinib), alone or in combination with chemotherapy, to reduce the CML burden, before undergoing allogeneic SCT. Response rates (major hematologic) with single-agent TKIs range from 30 to 50% in accelerated phase and from 20 to 30% in blastic phase.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 826.

choices.text: 3 consecutive years no local transmission in the state

questions.text: Intensified malaria control under the national framework for malaria elimination is done for :
questions.solution:
The national framework for eliminating malaria has the following goals:
 
  • By 2022, all 26 states that have cat 1, cat 2 or cat 3 status in 2014; Stop malaria transmission and No indigenous cases.
  • In all Indian states, malaria incidence will be less than 1 cases per 1,000 people by 2024.
  • indigenous transmission will be stopped in all Indian states by 2027.
  • malaria would be eradicated and re-establishment avoided by 2030.
      
  • States with API more than or equal to 1:  Technically speaking, this definition of intensified malaria control in a region is correct.
  • Zero incidence of malaria: Malaria incidence must be lessened rather than eliminated.
  • No longer a health problem: No, by 2024, the incidence will be fewer than 1/1000 cases.
  • 3 consecutive years no local transmission in the state: may be correct, but the criteria of 3 years are not true.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 314.

choices.text: It is activated by viral thymidine kinase
Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding FOSCARNET ?
questions.solution:
Foscarnet is the preferred medication for treating refractory HSV, VZV, and CMV
It can result in nephrotoxicity which can be reduced by preloading with normal saline.

It does not require activation by thymidine kinase.  Activation is necessary for nucleoside analogues like acyclovir.

It may result in hypo/hyperphosphatemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypo/hypercalcemia. As a result, routine serum electrolyte monitoring is necessary. It can cause genital ulceration as well.

questions.text: From the given options, which is the most likely diagnosis where X-ray shows a lytic lesion of the lower limb and the biopsy shows fibroblastic proliferation, osteoclast, and inflammatory cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) GCT
 
* Giant cell tumor (GCT)-
  • Another name for it is osteoclastoma.
  • Long bones' epiphyses are affected (MC-Distal femur).
  • The female to male ratio is 1.5 to 1.
  • The average age group is 35 years, and those over 20 years old account for 80% of cases.
  • Egg shell crackling when palpated; Jaffe's criterion is used to determine the Osteoclastoma's histological grade.
  • X-ray diagnosis: Soap bubble lesion.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1193.

questions.text: Which investigation would you order next in a case where a child presented with difficulty in walking and on biopsy of the hip some osteoclasts and grooved nuclei with eosinophil cytoplasm are present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is CD 1a marker 
 
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a possible diagnosis in the described situation.
  • LCH may involve the femur.
  • Langerhans cells contain a single, large nucleus that is distinctively folded or grooved (having a coffee-bean appearance), as well as a few small, unnoticeable nucleoli.
  • CD1a surface marker visualization is now thought to be sufficient to make the diagnosis of LCH.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text: What is the cause of Hydrops fetalis?
questions.solution:
• The most frequent infectious cause of hydrops fetalis is parvovirus Bl9, which also causes anemia by infecting fetal erythroid progenitor cells.
  • Severe anemia also causes high-output cardiac failure and hydrops fetalis.
  • Parvovirus is a single stranded DNA virus.
  • The receptor for parvovirus B-19 is CD-21 or complement receptor 2. 
     

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 213
